STUDENT LIFE IN JAPAN.
BY ROKURO NAKASKKO.

It was nearly a thousand years ago that the
Imperial University was opened for the instruction of the youths of the nobility. The
courses offered were in history, moral philosophy, jurisprudence and mathematics. Besides, the arts of medicine, soothsaying, almanac making, writing and painting were introduced from time to time. Many young
men were also sent by the government to
study abroad. Later on, about four or five
hundred years ago, the political condition of
the country had changed entirely, and the
country was divided up into so many petty
principalities, whose heads were, although
nominally subject to the throne of the one and
the same everlasting royal family, continually
engaged in warfare among each other, and
who had no leisure to pay attention to the cultivation of art and science. Then, the education passed into the hands of Buddhist monks,
and the higher culture was only preserved
within the Buddhist temples. About three
hundred years ago, with the unification of the
country under the royal sovereignty, schools
and seminaries were again established everywhere, and the education of the sons and
daughters of the nobles and warriors was
given, not only in the peaceful art and literature, but also in military drills. Indeed, the
art of fencing was the most prominent task in
these seminaries. In the meanwhile the sons
and daughters of merchants and peasants continued to get education through the Buddhist
monks. Thus my readers will be prepared to
understand how the religion (Buddhism) and
the education were so intimately interwoven
among the merchants and peasants, and how
the warlike spirit and the belles-lettres were
so inseparably amalgamated and developed
into the spirit of the chivalry which we are so

proud of' and which we call the "Yamatodamashie."
In this connection, it may not be uninteresting to quote what that great Commodore
Perry says in p. 58 of the introduction to his
report of the United States Japan Expedition:
"Xavier says that in his day there were four
academies in or near Miako (Kyoto), each
having between three and four thousand pupils; and he adds that much larger numbers
were taught at an institution near the city of
Bandone, and that such seminaries were universal throughout the empire. There would
seem to be something like a common school
system, for Meylau states that children of both
sexes and of all ranks are invariably sent to
rudimentary schools. Here the pupils are all
taught to read and write, and are initiated into
some knowledge of the history of their own
country. This much the meanest peasant
child is expected to learn. There are immense
numbers of cheap, easy books continually issuing from the Japanese press. Books innumerable of a higher order are provided for
the rich, and all, of both kinds, are profusely
illustrated with wood cuts. So that in our
modern inventions of stereotyping and printing in colors, and in our manufacture of cheap
literature for the people generally, Japan has
anticipated us by centuries. Reading is a favorite occupation with both sexes; and it is
said to be common in Japan to see, when the
weather permits, a group of ladies and gentlemen seated by a cool running stream, or in a
shady grove, each with a book."
In regard to this last point, I must say that
half a century ago, when ,Commodore Perry
visited my country, ladies and gentlemen may
have had such a fine time together. Today,
however, the society does not permit a college
young man and a college young lady to walk
together by a happy running stream, or to

Excepting the primary public schools, there is
almost no co-educational school at present.
So far as my knowledge goes, the only coeducational institution of high rank is Dr.
Hasegawa's Medical College in Tokyo. Beyond the age of fifteen, the girls and the boys
are temporarily and forcibly separated from
each other. Each sex goes by itself its own
way, and there is apparently a great abyss
lying between these two realms until the ceremony of the "turtle and crane," and of the
"pine-bamboo-and-plum-blossom" heals the
abyss and "gives forth a good tune by pairing
the coarse with the tender and the strong with
the mild." In my alma mater, the Doshish
University of Kyoto, there are college and
graduate departments for boys, and Girls' Department and Nurses' School, which is connected with a hospital. The boys' department
is separated from the girls' by several hundred
yards of the intervening space, which is occupied by resident 'houses. There is no communication for week days between these two
artificially separated realms. But lo! every
Sunday morning, at a quarter of nine, there
comes a long procession of fair maidens, one
to three hundred in number, winding their
way along the wall of the old time-honored
Imperial Palace. Listen to the echo of their
lightly-treaded, velvet-matted, hollow-clogs
made of pavlonia imperialis. Hearken to the
chirping and the murmuring of these "girlscholars" (for we do not say school girls, but
"she-scholars" or "girl-scholars"). They are
coming for the morning service at our church!
They enter the church, take their seats together by themselves in the eastern wing.
Then the boys come in pell-mell and take
their seats anywhere they can find, without
any rule and without any order, but most
scrupulously avoiding the girls' pews. And
eo things go on.
The third of November brings around annually the great national holiday for celebration of the Emperor's Birthday. This also

brings the "Arbor Day" for the public school
children. The boys of my alma mater keep
on this day a great boat race on the Lake
Biwa, the largest lake of the country. The
students of all the colleges in the neighborhood are invited and requested to send champions for the intercollegiate race as the climax
of the day. And here, also, you notice a
group of fair maidens of the Doshisha Girls'
Department and the Nurses' School, seated
on the best point of the promontory, headed
by the widow of late President Neesiiima, and
smiting over their brethrens' enthusiastic combatting with other rival colleges. But these
maidens are mute; to talk is for them to blush;
only they may from time to time send prizes
to the winners.
Beside boat rowing, baseball is also just as
much popular among college students. But
all these are purely voluntary games in contradistinction from the compulsory military
drill of four hours a week. After being graduated from these colleges, they must still fulfill one year's military service, after which
they get the rank of second lieutenant of the
landwehr. Then they are left free either to
continue in military service or to pursue ordinary civil life. Thus the combination of
warlike occupation and literary study, which
was existing in Old Japan in a so grotesque
scale, is now being revived, compelled by the
international relations of New Japan, under a
better form. The habit of college students of
Japan is very rough and coarse, and they ut •
terly lack the refined gentlemanliness of the
Johns Hopkins students. The emphasis laid
on the military drill tends to make them combative, and it is not infrequent that a whole
class combines in a "strike," as they call it,
and refuse to attend a certain unpopular professor's recitation, thus compelling the trustees to dismiss that particular professor.
The greatest defect in Japanese college
students' life is, however, the total absence of
the healthy, refining and uplifting influence of
noble Christian manhood and womanhood.

RUDYARD KIPLING.

We have toiled with Mr. Kipling so far up
the hill, that we refuse indignantly to allow
him to set his face in any wise but toward the
top. We, who have known Mulvaney, and
loved him; who have assisted (in the character of peeping Tom) at the conquests of Mrs.
Hauksbee; who have gone a long day's journey into that "cleaner, greener land" where,
Upon the road which leads to 'Mandalay, waits
a Hindoo maiden for her absent British soldier—how shall we be content with so much
small talk between the low-pressure cylinder
and the forward collision-bulkhead, between
the grey Ape and the black Buck, between the
Pittsburg Consolidation and the Boston Compound?
If the gods, for our virtue, should grant us
three wishes, we would desire, firstly, secondly
and thirdly, that Mr. Kipling become not a
literary globe-trotter. Let him stay at home
in Simla, and tell us more of Thomas Atkins;
for McPhee cannot tell a tale like Mulvaney,
and it is vain to say that Mrs. McPhee has
taken the place of Dinah Shadd: we desire her
alone.
We cannot read the Bridge-Builders, the
Walking Delegate, the Ship That Found Herself, and .007, without wishing that the wild
beasts, and twin-screws, and locomotives of
those stories would soon remember the modesty with which they are wont to refrain from
talking; but the Tomb of His Ancestors takes
us home again; and excitement runs high in
our blood, when we learn how the Archangels,
.to their sorrow, came down to play polo with
the Skidars. The Brushwood Boy, however,
has first place in our heart, and for many reasons—because we love the kind of man he is:
who has not lost, in the strength and beauty
of his fine Anglo-Saxon manhood, the purity,

because it is very seldom indeed that the artist
attains a finer perfection in his art, than when
he succeeds in showing together without offense the high lights of the broad noonday of
life, blended subtly, as they are in every
man's soul, with the strange shadows that yet
linger from the early morning of childhood;
but, chiefly, because we had the happiness of
reading the story with one whose eyes are the
book in which we most delight to read.
GOETHE.
MIGNON.

Know'st thou the land where lemon blossom
blows,
Where, 'mid dark leaves, the golden orange
glows?
Soft sigh the winds from out the azure sky,
Nor myrtles move, nor sways the laurel high.
Know'st thou it well?
For there, for there,
I would with thee,0 my beloved, fare.
Know'st thou the house whose roof tall pillars
bear?
Bright gleam the halls, in light the chambers
flare,
Where marble pictures stand and gaze on me:
"What,0 poor child! hath man then done to
thee?"
Know'st thou it well?
For there, for there,
I would with thee,0 my protector! fare.
Know'st thou the mount whose road the mist
enshrouds,
Where picks the mule his path among the
clouds?
Where dwell in caves the Dragon's ancient
brood,
Where roll the rocks, and over them the flood?
Know'st thou it well?
For there, for there,
Where leads our path, 0 father! let us fare!

CAROL WIGHT.

STUDENT LIFE IN JAPAN.
BY ROKURO NAKASKKO.

It was nearly a thousand years ago that the
Imperial University was opened for the instruction of the youths of the nobility. The
courses offered were in history, moral philosophy, jurisprudence and mathematics. Besides, the arts of medicine, soothsaying, almanac making, writing and painting were introduced from time to time. Many young
men were also sent by the government to
study abroad. Later on, about four or five
hundred years ago, the political condition of
the country had changed entirely, and the
country was divided up into so many petty
principalities, whose heads were, although
nominally subject to the throne of the one and
the same everlasting royal family, continually
engaged in warfare among each other, and
who had no leisure to pay attention to the cultivation of art and science. Then, the education passed into the hands of Buddhist monks,
and the higher culture was only preserved
within the Buddhist temples. About three
hundred years ago, with the unification of the
country under the royal sovereignty, schools
and seminaries were again established everywhere, and the education of the sons and
daughters of the nobles and warriors was
given, not only in the peaceful art and literature, but also in military drills. Indeed, the
art of fencing was the most prominent task in
these seminaries. In the meanwhile the sons
and daughters of merchants and peasants continued to get education through the Buddhist
monks. Thus my readers will be prepared to
understand how the religion (Buddhism) and
the education were so intimately interwoven
among the merchants and peasants, and how
the warlike spirit and the belles-lettres were
so inseparably amalgamated and developed
into the spirit of the chivalry which we are so

proud of' and which we call the "Yamatodamashie."
In this connection, it may not be uninteresting to quote what that great Commodore
Perry says in p. 58 of the introduction to his
report of the United States Japan Expedition:
"Xavier says that in his day there were four
academies in or near Miako (Kyoto), each
having between three and four thousand pupils; and he adds that much larger numbers
were taught at an institution near the city of
Bandone, and that such seminaries were universal throughout the empire. There would
seem to be something like a common school
system, for Meylau states that children of both
sexes and of all ranks are invariably sent to
rudimentary schools. Here the pupils are all
taught to read and write, and are initiated into
some knowledge of the history of their own
country. This much the meanest peasant
child is expected to learn. There are immense
numbers of cheap, easy books continually issuing from the Japanese press. Books innumerable of a higher order are provided for
the rich, and all, of both kinds, are profusely
illustrated with wood cuts. So that in our
modern inventions of stereotyping and printing in colors, and in our manufacture of cheap
literature for the people generally, Japan has
anticipated us by centuries. Reading is a favorite occupation with both sexes; and it is
said to be common in Japan to see, when the

half a century ago, when ,Commodore Perry

Excepting the primary public schools, there is
almost no co-educational school at present.
So far as my knowledge goes, the only coeducational institution of high rank is Dr.
Hasegawa's Medical College in Tokyo. Beyond the age of fifteen, the girls and the boys
are temporarily and forcibly separated from
each other. Each sex goes by itself its own
way, and there is apparently a great abyss
lying between these two realms until the ceremony of the "turtle and crane," and of the
"pine-bamboo-and-plum-blossom" heals the
abyss and "gives forth a good tune by pairing
the coarse with the tender and the strong with
the mild." In my alma mater, the Doshish
University of Kyoto, there are college and
graduate departments for boys, and Girls' Department and Nurses' School, which is connected with a hospital. The boys' department
is separated from the girls' by several hundred
yards of the intervening space, which is occupied by resident 'houses. There is no communication for week days between these two
artificially separated realms. But lo! every
Sunday morning, at a quarter of nine, there
comes a long procession of fair maidens, one
to three hundred in number, winding their
way along the wall of the old time-honored
Imperial Palace. Listen to the echo of their
lightly-treaded, velvet-matted, hollow-clogs
made of pavlonia imperialis. Hearken to the
chirping and the murmuring of these "girlscholars" (for we do not say school girls, but
"she-scholars" or "girl-scholars"). They are
coming for the morning service at our church!
They enter the church, take their seats together by themselves in the eastern wing.
Then the boys come in pell-mell and take
their seats anywhere they can find, without
any rule and without any order, but most
scrupulously avoiding the girls' pews. And
eo things go on.
The third of November brings around annually the great national holiday for celebration of the Emperor's Birthday. This also

brings the "Arbor Day" for the public school
children. The boys of my alma mater keep
on this day a great boat race on the Lake
Biwa, the largest lake of the country. The
students of all the colleges in the neighborhood are invited and requested to send champions for the intercollegiate race as the climax
of the day. And here, also, you notice a
group of fair maidens of the Doshisha Girls'
Department and the Nurses' School, seated
on the best point of the promontory, headed
by the widow of late President Neesiiima, and
smiting over their brethrens' enthusiastic combatting with other rival colleges. But these
maidens are mute; to talk is for them to blush;
only they may from time to time send prizes
to the winners.
Beside boat rowing, baseball is also just as
much popular among college students. But
all these are purely voluntary games in contradistinction from the compulsory military
drill of four hours a week. After being graduated from these colleges, they must still fulfill one year's military service, after which
they get the rank of second lieutenant of the
landwehr. Then they are left free either to
continue in military service or to pursue ordinary civil life. Thus the combination of
warlike occupation and literary study, which
was existing in Old Japan in a so grotesque
scale, is now being revived, compelled by the
international relations of New Japan, under a
better form. The habit of college students of
Japan is very rough and coarse, and they ut •
terly lack the refined gentlemanliness of the
Johns Hopkins students. The emphasis laid
on the military drill tends to make them combative, and it is not infrequent that a whole
class combines in a "strike," as they call it,
and refuse to attend a certain unpopular professor's recitation, thus compelling the trustees to dismiss that particular professor.
The greatest defect in Japanese college
students' life is, however, the total absence of
the healthy, refining and uplifting influence of
noble Christian manhood and womanhood.

We have toiled with Mr. Kipling so far up
the hill, that we refuse indignantly to allow
him to set his face in any wise but toward the
top. We, who have known Mulvaney, and
loved him; who have assisted (in the character of peeping Tom) at the conquests of Mrs.
Hauksbee; who have gone a long day's journey into that "cleaner, greener land" where,
Upon the road which leads to 'Mandalay, waits
a Hindoo maiden for her absent British soldier—how shall we be content with so much
small talk between the low-pressure cylinder
and the forward collision-bulkhead, between
the grey Ape and the black Buck, between the
Pittsburg Consolidation and the Boston Compound?
If the gods, for our virtue, should grant us
three wishes, we would desire, firstly, secondly
and thirdly, that Mr. Kipling become not a
literary globe-trotter. Let him stay at home
in Simla, and tell us more of Thomas Atkins;
for McPhee cannot tell a tale like Mulvaney,
and it is vain to say that Mrs. McPhee has
taken the place of Dinah Shadd: we desire her
alone.
We cannot read the Bridge-Builders, the
Walking Delegate, the Ship That Found Herself, and .007, without wishing that the wild
beasts, and twin-screws, and locomotives of
those stories would soon remember the modesty with which they are wont to refrain from
talking; but the Tomb of His Ancestors takes
us home again; and excitement runs high in
our blood, when we learn how the Archangels,
.to their sorrow, came down to play polo with
the Skidars. The Brushwood Boy, however,
has first place in our heart, and for many reasons—because we love the kind of man he is:
who has not lost, in the strength and beauty
of his fine Anglo-Saxon manhood, the purity,

Know'st thou the land where lemon blossom
blows,
Where, 'mid dark leaves, the golden orange
glows?
Soft sigh the winds from out the azure sky,

Know'st thou it well?

Know'st thou the house whose roof tall pillars
bear?

flare,

"What,0 poor child! hath man then done to
thee?"
Know'st thou it well?
For there, for there,
I would with thee,0 my protector! fare.
Know'st thou the mount whose road the mist
enshrouds,
Where picks the mule his path among the
clouds?
Where dwell in caves the Dragon's ancient
brood,
Where roll the rocks, and over them the flood?
Know'st thou it well?
For there, for there,
Where leads our path, 0 father! let us fare!
